messages: b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:45): apart from attributes that contain URL, are there dangerous attributes that don't start with "on"?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:48): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, autofocus
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:49): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, srcdoc
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:49): actually, maybe srcdoc is harmless
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:49): no, only harmless when sandbox is defined iirc
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:50): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: good point on autofocus
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:50): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: what's dangerous with srcdoc? it's in a different origin, right?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (16:51): what counts as "dangerous"?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:52): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: stuff that would allow script to run in the wrong origin when the markup is inserted into a different-origin doc
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:52): oh, and style is a special case, of course
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:53): is srcdoc in a different origin by default?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (16:53): if the attacker can control all the attributes on an iframe element, then srcdoc is indeed dangerous
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:53): I thought it wasn't
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (16:53): but then, so is src
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:53): src is excluded already as it contains a URL
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (16:53): any attribute that takes a URL and happens to contain a javascript: URL is probably dangerous
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:53): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: huh. I thought the whole point of involving an iframe was to put srcdoc into a different origin
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:53): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: what's the attack?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (16:54): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, I think that is only true for <iframe srcdoc=test sandbox>
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (16:54): srcdoc can be in a unique origin if you sandbox the iframe
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:54): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: what's the attack that makes srcdoc dangerous if all attributes controlled that is?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (16:54): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: I don't know what threat you are defending against, you said "allow script to run in the wrong origin"
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (16:55): but srcdoc iframes can be same-origin with the parent and can run script
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:55): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: what's the point of srcdoc without sandboxing?
e83147fdd1c7a8c2b85b2d842011b173 (16:55): Paul: some in my group may be interested in this
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (16:55): so can iframes with a javascript: src
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:56): same-origin srcdoc seems like trouble. what's the point of ever allowing srcdoc to be same-origin? why use an iframe at all in that case?

e83147fdd1c7a8c2b85b2d842011b173 (16:56): Bruce: I missed the point of what a class attribute would accomplish, an input box needs more complicated data, if your have markup for that and allows that in your schema
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:56): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: yeah, URL attributes all need special attention
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (16:56): what's the use case here? are you trying to filter html by blacklisting?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:56): e83147fdd1c7a8c2b85b2d842011b173: are you in the wrong window?
e83147fdd1c7a8c2b85b2d842011b173 (16:57): oops sorry in mathml wg telecon..... :-)
e83147fdd1c7a8c2b85b2d842011b173 (16:57): don't understand these tab things, bye
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:02): http://tools.ietf.org/html/draft-bankoski-vp8-bitstream
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:06): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: interesting choice of venue
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (17:07): hmm. Intended status: Informational
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:08): it was also submitted on Jan 6
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:08): bit weird
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (17:09): This specification is made available under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 License [4].
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (17:09): I would have expected that to turn up sooner
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (17:12): does the IETF let you put your choice of license on an RFC? I thought you had to assign them copyright
8b3687499080633e1898fa1dd209ef81 (17:14): "Copyright (c) 2011 IETF Trust and the persons identified as the document authors.  All rights reserved." on page one, and CC-BY on page 148
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (17:14): http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Request_for_Comments#Status_.22informational.22

1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (17:15): >An informational RFC can be nearly anything from April 1 jokes over proprietary protocols up to widely recognized essential RFCs like Domain Name System Structure and Delegation (RFC 1591).
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (17:15): published on January 6, so might not be a joke
b5934067b4c7d9c30299478a245d4491 (17:15): ah, good old TCP/IP over Carrier Pigeon
1f58faf0d058f303f30239a369808167 (17:16): CCTV for pigeons?
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (17:16): yeah, it just seems to be a least-effort path to something that can be called a "standard"
